occurrences.line_text: In her the richesse of all heauenly grace
That did the house of Richesse from hell-mouth diuide.
Here Sleep, there Richesse, & Hel-gate the[m] both betwext.
And shewd of richesse such exceeding store,
Without respect of richesse or reward.
Of richest substaunce, that on earth might bee,
(Said he) then ransome of the richest knight,
Nor of ought else, that may be richest red,
And richlier by many partes arayd:
With sprincled pearle, and gold full richly drest,
And ornaments that richly were displaid;
Most false Duessa, royall richly dight,
And richly clad in robes of royaltye,
Braunched with gold & pearle, most richly wrought,
That was with royall arras richly dight,
Nor that proud towre of Troy, though richly guilt,
The which was all within most richly dight,
Causd his pauilion to be richly pight
Most richly made, but there no Monster did behold.
Yet wondrous faire she was, and richly clad
But in a Iacket quilted richly rare,
Amidst a ring most richly well enchaced,
Seeing at last her selfe from daunger rid,
To rid a wretched man from hands of hellish wight.
After that foster fowle he fiercely rid,
And streight that boaster prayd, with whom he rid,
She had not rid the mountenance of a flight,
And with his Lady to the Castle rid,
For though she were right glad, so rid to bee
Right glad was Calepine to be so rid
They had not ridden farre, when they might see
And ere that litle while they ridden had,
Vnto their lodgings then his guestes he riddes:
That he had red her Riddle, which no wight
Oft purposes, oft riddles he deuysd,
In wittie riddles, and in wise soothsayes,
The red bloud trickling staind the way, as he did ride.
Gan fairely couch his speare, and towards ride:
Do ride each other, vpon her to gaze:
The Gods stand gazing on, when she does ride
And greedy Auarice by him did ride,
To gaze on earthly wight, that with the Night durst ride.
Not throughly heald, vnreadie were to ride.
But got his ready steed, and fast away gan ride.
And towards him they gan in hast to ride,
I that hight Treuisan (quoth he) will ride
Whiles on her wearie iourney she did ride;
Does ride on both their backs, & faire her selfe doth saue.
So to his steed he got, and gan to ride,
But chiefly skill to ride, seemes a science
For well of yore he learned had to ride,
Soone to him raught, and fierce at him did ride,
Here may thy storme-bet vessell safely ride;
Whereon faire Florimell was wont to ride,
Sir knight why ride ye dumpish thus behind,
Which straight flew ope, and gaue her way to ride.
Vnto her Coch remounting, home did ride,
And with her alwaies ride, till he another get.
Hight Bruncheual the bold, who fiersly forth did ride.
And him against Sir Blandamour did ride
Vpon her first aduenture forth did ride,
The next day, as he on his way did ride,
Mongst Knights, when on aduentures they did ride,
And made it so to ride, as it aliue was found.
That as we ride together on our way,
In her great iron charet wonts to ride,
Till like a victor on his backe he ride,
So as she thus melancholicke did ride,
But on his first aduenture forward forth did ride.
The which themselues prepard thorough the foord to ride.
Being vnhable else alone to ride;
Withouten armes or steede to ride vpon,
To throw his rider: who can quickly ryse
To stumble, that his rider nigh he cast;
Through which the rider downe doth fall through ouersight.
Did warne his rider be vppon his gard;
T'obey their riders hest, as seemed good.
Whose luckelesse riders late were ouerthrowen;
And him beside rides fierce reuenging VVrath,
And on a Palfrey rides more white then snow,
He rides (said Turpine) there not farre afore,
Streight was the passage like a ploughed ridge,
Came riding on a Lion rauenous,
And eke those masked Ladies riding them beside.
Which Blandamour had riding by his side:
By any ridling skill, or commune wit.
The swelling Splene, and Frenzy raging rife,
And euer fickle fortune rageth rife,
And threw it to the ground, enraged rife,
Happy, who can abstaine, when Rancour rife
Auauntage, whilest his foe did rage most rife;
Whence forth it breakes in sighes and anguish rife,
Which in these troubled bowels raignes, & rageth rife.
And feeling by his pulses beating rife,
And euery one threw forth reproches rife
Thence streames of purple bloud issuing rife,
The more was Claribell enraged rife
Regardlesse of her wounds, yet bleeding rife,
He pluckt a bough; out of whose rift there came
The mightie trunck halfe rent, with ragged rift
With dreadfull poyse is from the mayneland rift,
That hart of flint a sunder could haue rift:
And with rich metall loaded euery rift,
And threatneth downe to throw his ragged rift
Whilest through their rifts the ruddie bloud did showre
Tho to his daughter Rigan he repayrd,
With his well rigged boate: They go abord,
Right faithfull true he was in deede and word,
Right well Sir knight ye haue aduised bin,
What not by right, she cast to win by guile,
And all that he by right or wrong could find,
Arriued there they passed in forth right;
Right glad with him to haue increast their crew:
That knew not, whether right he went, or else astray.
In greene vine leaues he was right fitly clad;
And right and wrong ylike in equall ballaunce waide.
And if that either to that shield had right,
He neuer meant with words, but swords to plead his right.
To you th'inheritance belongs by right
So th'one for wrong, the other striues for right:
So th'one for wrong, the other striues for right,
To seeke his kindred, and the lignage right,
And euer lou'd to fight for Ladies right,
For he that made the same, was knowne right well
Right so; (quoth he) but he, that neuer would,
Had throwne to ground the vnregarded right:
Be iudge ye heauens, that all things right esteeme,
So forth they went, the Dwarfe them guiding euer right.
And smote off quite his right leg by the knee,
His name Ignaro did his nature right aread.
And eke as pledges firme, right hands together ioynd.
What iustice can but iudge against thee right,
For he, that once hath missed the right way,
His name was Zele, that him right well became,
Right cleanly clad in comely sad attire;
That chose the narrow path, or seeke the right:
And in her right hand bore a cup of gold,
With goodly counsell and aduisement right;
She was right ioyous of her iust request,
Or gan to shrinke, or from the right to stray,
In face of iudgement he their right would plead,
Is not from hence the way, that leadeth right
But glauncing by forth passed forward right;
For that reprochfull fall right fowly he disdaynd.
And sad habiliments right well beseene;
And bowed low, that her right well became,
But he for nought would stay his passage right,
For he already plighted his right hand
Ne weene my right with strength adowne to tread,
Right well I wote most mighty Soueraine,
A right good knight, and true of word ywis:
With right hands plighted, pledges of good will.
Ye bene right hard amated, gratious Lord,
Where when the knight arriu'd, he was right well
By tortious wrong, or whom bereau'd of right.
Both knights and Ladies forth right angry far'd,
Their sharpe assault right boldly did rebut,
And not regard dew right and iust desarts?
No measure in her mood, no rule of right,
Thou little wotest, what this right hand can:
Whose right haunch earst my stedfast arrow strake?
Would from the right way seeke to draw him wide,
Burnt I do burne. Right well beseemed it,
His am I Atin, his in wrong and right,
And to his brest it selfe intended right:
To which right well the wise do giue that name,
Because he had not well mainteind his right,
Ah Dame, perdie ye haue not doen me right,
Me litle needed from my right way to haue straid.
Him Atin spying, knew right well of yore,
He knew right well, and him attonce disarmd:
From the worldes eye, and from her right vsaunce?
In his right hand an yron club he held,
Her face right wondrous faire did seeme to bee,
Not to debate the chalenge of your right,
Right sowre, & feele the law, the which thou hast defast.
It seizd in his right side, and there the dint did stay.
And said; Faire Son, great God thy right hand blesse,
Had lost, he by him spide, right glad he grew,
And entertained them right fairely, as befell.
They did obeysaunce, as beseemed right,
Thence backe againe faire Alma led them right,
That was right faire and fresh as morning rose,
That was right faire, and modest of demaine,
He now was growne right wise, and wondrous sage.
Right firme & strong, though somewhat they declind;
Which though from earth it be deriued right,
Right well recur'd, and did away that blame
That knowes no kinred, nor regardes no right,
So settled he his kingdome, and confirmd his right.
Without full point, or other Cesure right,
Of whom all Faeryes spring, and fetch their lignage right.
But let them pas, whiles wind and weather right
And many arrowes vnder his right side,
Fiercely aduaunst his valorous right arme,
Threw at his foe, who was right well aware
But passed forth, and lookt still forward right,
And with her right the riper fruit did reach,
Right hard it was, for wight, which did it heare,
And all that while, right ouer him she hong,
The way they came, the same retourn'd they right,
But if in liuing colours, and right hew,
Restord, and sory wounds right well recured,
And to recouer right for such, as wrong did grieue.
In which the sword was seruant vnto right;
So vnto wrong to yield my wrested right:
But mote I weet of you, right curteous knight,
Defending Ladies cause, and Orphans right,
What time king Ryence raign'd, and dealed right,
A looking glasse, right wondrously aguiz'd,
Then I auow to thee, by wrong or right
All contrary, for she the right did shunne,
Who was the Lord of Mathrauall by right,
Shall take the crowne, that was his fathers right,
Themselues they forth conuayd, & passed forward right.
Her noble deeds, ne her right course for ought forsooke.
Right as he entring was into the flood,
Angell, or Goddesse do I call thee right?
Ministreth matter fit, which tempred right
Right in the middest of that Paradise,
T'adore thing so diuine as beauty, were but right.
His late miswandred wayes now to remeasure right.
To scale the skyes, and put Ioue from his right:
Right sore I feare, least with vnworthy blames
Had them surprised. At last auizing right,
She came in presence with right comely grace,
Indeed he said (if I remember right,)
And ranne into her louers armes right fast;
In better quarrell, then defence of right,
And her swords point directing forward right,
Which his right hand vnarmed fearefully did wield.
In her right hand a firebrand she did tosse
Forgetfull of his safety, hath his right way lost.
With that the darts which his right hand did straine,
Did yield himselfe right willing to prolong his date.
For Amoret right fearefull was and faint,
Right well deserued as his duefull meed,
That fairest Amoret was his by right,
The Seneschall was cal'd to deeme the right,
Now freely drew, and found right safe assurance theare.
And now himselfe he fitted had right well,
I did assay, that me right dearely cost,
And eke because his loue he wonne by right:
As ye haue done for me: the left hand rubs the right.
Render therefore therein to me my right,
Thereto she was right faire, when so her face
And pledges pawnd the same to keepe a right,
Right practicke was Sir Priamond in fight,
That he for paine himselfe n'ote right vpreare,
As in reuersion of his brothers right;
Was with the force nigh feld whilst his right foot did slyde.
In her right hand a rod of peace shee bore,
That who so winnes her, may her haue by right:
His life he then would spend to iustifie his right.
But certes his right name was otherwize,
To Britomart was giuen by good right;
Yet nathelesse to her, as her dew right,
Who was right glad to gaine so goodly meed:
And he himselfe his right would eke releasse:
Right fit to rend the food, on which he fared.
He wist right well, that it was Britomart,
And if I hap to fayle, you shall recure my right.
And therewithall at him right furiously she strooke.
He was therewith right wondrously dismayd,
Right plaine appeard, though she it would dissemble,
I can not vnto you aread a right.
And backe returned with right heauie mind,
But with his craggy club in his right hand,
Yet had it bene right hard him to withstand,
He held the Lady forth before him right,
Right sore agrieued at her sharpe reproofe,
Him seemed oft he heard his owne right name.
That was a Ruby of right perfect hew,
But that sweet bird departing, flew forth right
Had knowne right well with colourd ribbands drest:
The one right feeble through the euill rate
Tho when they both recouered were right well,
Whereat the Prince full wrath, his strong right hand
But that same dwarfe right sorie seem'd and sad,
Till better him bethinking of the right,
And in that right should by all knights be shielded:
Whose right she is, where euer she be straide,
The which right well her workes diuine did shew:
And vnto Venus grace the gate doth open right.
Right in the midst the Goddesse selfe did stand
Doing him selfe, and teaching others to doe right.
To whom the right hereof it selfe hath sold;
Or ought more hard, then thinke to reckon right.
Haue care of right, or ruth of wretches wrong,
Right sorrowfully mourning her bereaued cares.
And was right ioyous, that she gotten had
Right so himselfe did Marinell vpreare,
Right now is wrong, and wrong that was is right,
Right now is wrong, and wrong that was is right,
In better case, ne keepes his course more right,
That both to good and bad he dealeth right,
And rule his people right, as he doth recommend.
And wrong repressed, and establisht right,
Chose Artegall to right her to restore;
There she him taught to weigh both right and wrong
In all the skill of deeming wrong and right,
Would not so rest contented with his right,
Then to approue his right with speare and shield.
And sayd, Now sure this doubtfull causes right
And both the liuing Lady claime your right,
Then to defend the feeble in their right,
Right in the midst, whereas they brest to brest
In whose right hands great power is contayned,
In stead of right me seemes great wrong dost shew,
That not a dram was missing of their right,
The right or wrong, the false or else the trew?
But he could iustly weigh the wrong or right.
Now take the right likewise, sayd Artegale,
So first the right he put into one scale;
Yet all the wrongs could not a litle right downe lay.
For they doe nought but right or wrong betoken;
But in the mind the doome of right must bee;
But set the truth and set the right aside,
For truth is one, and right is euer one.
But right sate in the middest of the beame alone.
But he the right from thence did thrust away,
For it was not the right, which he did seeke;
To chalenge all in right of Florimell,
And rather had to lose, then trie in armes his right.
By law of armes there neede ones right to trie,
Yet further right by tokens to descrie,
Artegall dealeth right betwixt
For powre is the right hand of Iustice truely hight.
By what good right doe you withhold this day?
What other right (quoth he) should you esteeme,
Your right is good (sayd he) and so I deeme,
By what right doe you claime to be your owne?
What other right (quoth he) should you esteeme,
Your right is good (sayd he) and so I deeme,
For equall right in equall things doth stand,
And so the threasure yours is Bracidas by right.
But Bracidas and Lucy were right glad,
And each one had his right. Then Artegall
Right true: but faulty men vse oftentimes
In which condition I right now did stand.
From that first flaw him selfe right well defended.
Many braue knights, whose names right well he knew,
And thereto did himselfe right well behaue,
What right is it, that he should thraldome find,
And eke with gratefull seruice me right well apay.
Heard to the end, she was right sore bestad,
But still right downe, and in her thought did hide
The felnesse of her heart, right fully bent
Which when their Host perceiu'd, right discontent
With sight whereof she was dismayd right sore,
She there remain'd, but with right wary heede,
Then this same vertue, that doth right define:
Right in their wrongs, are rul'd by righteous lore
She did prostrate, and with right humble hart,
And therefore loth to loose her right away,
To breake all bonds of law, and rules of right.
That Damzell, led her to the Souldans right.
In glistering armes right goodly well beseene,
But the braue Prince for honour and for right,
Vnto that Damzell in her Ladies right,
Loe now, right noble knights, arriu'd ye bee
For she whylome (as ye mote yet right well
That she of death was guiltie found by right,
he slayes in Belges right.
But to preserue inuiolated right,
Yet neuer doth from doome of right depart:
That should their powre against her right oppose.
And thence vnto the castle marched right,
And meeting him right in the middle race,
Right in the middest of the threshold lay,
Who with right humble thankes him goodly greeting,
With her two sonnes, right deare of her beloued,
Belge vnto her right.
That right long time is ouerborne of wrong,
Yet at the last she will her owne cause right.
To which they had no right, nor any wrongfull state.
Full nobly mounted in right warlike wize;
He wox right blyth, as he had got thereby,
But by their trueth and by the causes right:
And then and there for triall of her right
And right and wrong most cruelly confound:
He thether came, but for to trie the right
Which none durst breake, though many would right faine
Right in the flanke him strooke with deadly dreare,
And Talus to reuoke from the right way,
From his right course, but still the way did hold
Right so from you all goodly vertues well
Right so in Faery court it did redound,
Which I pursue, of whom I am right glad
Will it auenge, and pay thee with thy right:
To pay each with his owne is right and dew.
There he remaind with them right well agreed,
In his right hand he held a trembling dart,
In which he had good right gaynst all, that it gainesayd.
To lend him day his better right to trie,
Now sure (then said Sir Calidore) and right
And lost the crowne, which should my head by right adorne.
Ripe yeares of reason, my right to maintaine.
I may beare armes, and learne to vse them right;
For though she were right glad, so rid to bee
That which your selfe haue earst ared so right?
Right glad was Calepine to be so rid
And did right noble deedes, the which elswhere are showne.
T'amend what was amisse, and put in right aray.
That seem'd the spoile of some right well renownd.
For he right well in Leaches craft was seene,
For greater force there needs to maintaine wrong, then right.
Whom he likewise right sorely did constraine,
My due reward, the which right well I deeme
That way to them he gaue forth right to pas.
And euen as his right hand adowne descends,
Giuen to Calidore, as his due right;
Crownd with a rosie girlond, that right well
Right happy thou, that mayst them freely see:
Right sory I, (saide then Sir Calidore,)
Right well knew Coridon his owne late sheepe,
Whereof right glad they seem'd, and offer made
Were dead, right so as Coridon had taught:
And with their litle stings right felly fare;
Right so it fares with me in this long way,
For Bellamour knew Calidore right well,
But he right well aware, his rage to ward,
And fared like a feend, right horrible in hew.
The righteous man, to make him daily fall?
By righteous sentence of th'Almighties law:
That Mercy in the end his righteous soule might saue.
Thou doest the prayers of the righteous sead
What booteth then the good and righteous deed,
Doest to thy people righteous doome aread,
For that to her he seem'd best skild in righteous lore.
And next her selfe her righteous ballance hanging bee.
Then answered the righteous Artegall,
That, which he doth with righteous doome decide,
Would ye remit it to some righteous man.
Right in their wrongs, are rul'd by righteous lore
The righteous Knight, that is thy faithfull louer.
Where righteous Artegall her late exyled;
Which vnto them was dealing righteous doome.
Vpon the righteous Themis: those they say
The noble Prince, and righteous Artegall,
Of loue, and righteousnesse, and well to donne,
In holy righteousnesse, without rebuke or blame.
If goodnesse find no grace, nor righteousnesse no meed?
If good find grace, and righteousnesse reward,
Then with a few to walke the rightest way;
Yet rightfull kingdome she had none at all,
That would his rightfull rauine rend away:
Be wonne their rightfull causes downe to tread:
For truth is strong, her rightfull cause to plead,
That more to mighty ha[n]ds, the[n] rightfull cause doth trust.
And were there rightfull cause of difference,
But he the rightfull owner of that steed,
From rightfull owner by vnrighteous lot,
Ne forst his rightfull owner to offend,
By such, as claymd themselues Brutes rightfull haires,
But would some rightfull cause pretend, though rightly nought.
And all the depth of rightfull doome was taught
Their greatest glory, for their rightfull deedes,
And to his damzell as their rightfull meed,
His name was meeke Obedience rightfully ared.
Wherefore Morddure it rightfully is hight.
And said, Deare daughter rightly may I rew
Defyld those sacred waues, it rightly hot
Which who hath skill them rightly to haue chusd,
That vnto thee due worship I may rightly frame.
And faire Philotime she rightly hight,
And his large bountie rightly doth areed.
Is rightly cald, th'author of life and light;
Which was by him BELPHEBE rightly rad.
Yet glasse was not, if one did rightly deeme,
The Ouze, whom men doe Isis rightly name;
But would some rightfull cause pretend, though rightly nought.
For worthy thou of her doest rightly seeme.
His name is hight Pollente, rightly so
In cyphers strange, that few could rightly read,
Their good, that none them rightly may reproue
Yet boldly answer'd, as he rightly might;
Perdy thou peasant Knight, mightst rightly reed
Therefore it rightly cleeped was mount Acidale.
Her to demaund, and chalenge as their rights,
By all meanes to maintaine that castels ancient rights.
And battailes doubtfull proofe their rights to try,
When they had seene and heard her doome a rights
Yet heauens them selues, that fauour feeble rights,
And eke themselues too rudely rigorous,
And fiercely ran at him with rigorous might:
It vaine she thought with rigorous vprore
With rigour so outrageous he smitt,
And at his foe with furious rigour smites,
But beare the rigour of his bold mesprise,
Guyon broke downe, with rigour pittilesse;
To him he turned, and with rigour fell
To graunt her boone, and rigour to abate,
Whose raging rigour neither steele nor bras
Relent the rigour of your wrathfull will,
With sufferaunce soft, which rigour can abate,
Of breath, their raging rigour to relent,
No words may rate, nor rigour him remoue
When so it needs with rigour to dispence.
Great warriours oft their rigour to represse,
